phrase.item: Once there were four brothers
One of them was bald.
Once the brothers drove the bald shepherd out of the house. Then they separated from each other.
The bald shepherd built a house for himself, and sowed wheat.
When the wheat ripens, then his brothers come and burn it down.
He puts the ashes from the wheat into a sack, going to one of the valleys, runs into a man.
The man asks: "What have you got in this sack?"
He says: "I've got gold in this sack."
The other man says: "Let me have a quick look: I've never seen gold before."
He says: "You've got a bad eye." The other man says: "I've got a very good eye." And he unties the sack.
But the sack's got nothing but ashes naturally.
He grabs the man, [starts to] hit [him, saying] that: "Your eye is very bad
My gold turned to ashes!
Now go to the king, he'll kill you!"
The man tells the bald shepherd: "Don't take me to the King,
I'll give you a camel, fifteen head of small horned livestock." The bald shepherd says: "All right." The other man gives him a camel and some sheep and goats.
Then the bald shepherd heads home.
(When he comes home), the brothers tell him: "Who gave you the camel?"
The bald shepherd says: "At the bazaar they're trading ashes for a camel."
(Then) his brothers burn down their own wheat, pour the ashes into a sack, bring it to the bazaar, cry out: "Won't you [come and] get some wheat ashes?"
People start to laugh at them.
The brothers get embarrassed.
Then they come home, beat their brother like a donkey. And they kill his mother.
The bald shepherd puts his mother on the donkey, goes to a certain place, (and there's) a man with sheep and goats there.
He comes up to the bald shepherd , takes the donkey by the mane.
At that, the donkey jumped, (and) the mother's corpse fell off the donkey.
Then the bald shepherd grabs that man, (screams): "You killed my mother!
Now go to the emir, he will put you in chains!"
That man says: "Don't take me to the emir.
Here, take all this here livestock of mine for yourself!"
So he drives that livestock away [with him].
He comes home, the brothers start to beat him: "Who gave you this livestock?"
He says: "You don't know? At the bazaar they're trading corpse[s] (for livestock)."
Then they also kill their mother, put her on their donkey, go to the bazaar.
(There) they hawk [their wares]: "Won't you [come and] get a corpse?"
They start getting yelled at.
(Then) they bury their mother there, come home again.
And they beat the bald shepherd again.
He is crying. Then they put the bald shepherd in a sack, shoulder the sack, carry [him] off to the river to drown.
(Along the way) (nature calls and) they make a pit stop, (and) leave him.
Through the sack he now sees a shepherd approach.
Then bald shepherd cries: "I refuse to be the emir!"
That old man comes up, says: "Let me climb into this sack!"
And he climbs into the sack, the other man ties it up.
And the bald shepherd heads home, driving the livestock.
The brothers (upon their return) ask him: "Where did you get this herd?"
The bald shepherd says: "There are so many sheep and goats in the river, come with me right now, I'll show them to you!"
They go with him.
The bald shepherd lines goats up along the river bank, says, (pointing at the water): "There they are, the goats, quickly, jump!"
They [the brothers] jump into the water, drown.
And the bald shepherd returns, saying to himself: "(Finally) I got rid of my brothers." He makes his brothers' wives his servants.
And from then on he lives in happiness and prosperity.
